activities.title: Fruit & Veggie Basket Exploration

materials.name: Basket with 3‚Äì4 real fruits/veggies (banana, apple, orange, cucumber)
Small cloth mat
Wipes for hands

steps.text: Seat children in a semi-circle. Place the basket on a mat and say: 'Let‚Äôs see what foods we have today!'
Take out one item at a time, clearly name it, let each child touch/smell briefly, and repeat the name slowly.
Place fruits on one side of the mat and vegetables on the other, saying 'fruit' and 'vegetable' each time.
Invite children to hand you a food when named (e.g., 'Can you give me the banana?').

observe: Child attends and orients to the named food.
Child attempts to imitate the word/sound.
Emerging recognition of fruit vs vegetable.
variations: Easier: Use only 2 highly familiar items (banana, apple).
Harder: Introduce one unfamiliar item (kiwi/capsicum) and scaffold naming.
cautions: Supervise closely to prevent biting/eating during exploration.
Ensure surfaces and hands are clean.

links.meetsExit: Child approximates or uses 1‚Äì2 food words.

activities.title: Food Feel & Match (Textures)

materials.name: Two bowls: 'smooth' items (boiled potato, apple) & 'bumpy' items (orange, corn cob)
Tray & cloth for cleanup

steps.text: Show the 'smooth' bowl. Model slow hand exploration and say 'smooooth' while the child feels the item.
Show the 'bumpy' bowl. Model touching the bumps and say 'bum-py' while the child explores.
Mix two items on a tray and invite the child to place them back in the correct bowl with labeling help.

observe: Child explores textures with hands without avoidance.
Child follows adult cue for smooth vs bumpy.
variations: Easier: Present only one smooth and one bumpy item.
Harder: Present 3‚Äì4 mixed items and prompt independent sort.
cautions: Confirm no allergies to items used.

links.meetsExit: Child demonstrates awareness of texture difference by matching 1 item.

activities.title: Edible vs Not Edible Sort

materials.name: Tray with mixed safe items: banana, carrot stick, spoon, soft block, plastic fruit toy
Two bowls with picture labels: 'mouth' (food) and 'hand' (not food)

steps.text: Say: 'Some things are food. Some things are not food.' Show the bowls and their picture labels.
Pick one item and ask 'Can we eat this?' Model 'yes' or 'no' gestures and place in correct bowl.
Invite each child to sort one item with supportive prompts ('Where should this go?').

observe: Child shows understanding of non-food items.
Child uses gesture/word for yes/no with cue.
variations: Easier: Use only one edible and one non-edible item.
Harder: Add lookalikes (real vs plastic fruit) to deepen concept.
cautions: Never allow mouthing of non-food items.

links.meetsExit: Child sorts 2 items accurately by category with minimal cue.

activities.title: Color Match: Red & Yellow Foods

materials.name: Two color mats/cards: red and yellow
4‚Äì6 picture cards or toy foods (tomato, strawberry; banana, corn)

steps.text: Show red mat and place a red food picture on it, saying 'red' clearly. Repeat with yellow mat/foods.
Present one picture to a child and prompt 'Where does this go? Red or yellow?'
Praise attempts; model correction gently if needed and repeat with another item.

observe: Child attends to and begins to match by color.
Child points/places food picture on matching mat.
variations: Easier: Use only 2‚Äì3 very clear examples.
Harder: Add an orange or green card to extend matching.
cautions: Avoid overstimulation: present one card at a time.
Keep pieces large to avoid choking hazards.

links.meetsExit: Child matches 2 pictures to correct color mat with cue.

activities.title: Shape Snack Builder (No-Eat Play)

materials.name: Safe play 'food' shapes (toy or laminated cutouts): circles (cucumber rounds), squares (bread), triangles (slice)
Placemats or trays

steps.text: Show each shape and name it (circle/square/triangle). Place 1‚Äì2 examples on a tray.
Invite children to place a circle on top of a circle outline, then a square on a square, etc.
Support simple building: 'Circle on square! Yum pretend sandwich!' (No eating.)

observe: Child visually matches shape to outline/peer model.
Child tolerates brief turn-taking while waiting.
variations: Easier: Offer only one shape type at a time.
cautions: Use large pieces; no real eating in this play.
Monitor mouthing‚Äîreplace with larger pieces if needed.

links.meetsExit: Child places at least one matching shape with cue.

activities.title: Taste Taps (Micro-Tasting with Consent)

materials.name: Tiny dabs on tasting spoons: sweet (banana mash), sour (mild lemon-water), salty (very mild saline), plain (water)
Consent list & allergy checks, wipes

steps.text: Confirm parental consent/allergy clearance. Seat children and explain: 'Small tastes today.'
Offer one taste at a time (e.g., sweet). Model 'tap' with your lips. Child may touch tongue briefly or decline.
Label: 'sweet', 'sour', 'salty' or 'plain' and watch facial reactions; discontinue if child resists.

observe: Child indicates preference/aversion via facial expression/gesture.
Child accepts or refuses taste appropriately.
variations: Harder: Add gentle comparison (sweet vs sour).
cautions: Strict allergy/consent protocol; sanitize between children.
Stop immediately at any sign of distress.

links.meetsExit: Child experiences at least one safe taste with regulation.

activities.title: Scoop & Pour: Grain Station

materials.name: Large bin with dry grains (rice/dal) or big pasta shapes (for safety)
Large spoons/scoops, 2‚Äì3 wide-mouthed bowls
Tray and broom/pan for cleanup

steps.text: Model scooping from the bin and pouring into a wide bowl slowly. Narrate: 'scoop‚Ä¶ pour‚Ä¶'
Invite children one at a time to scoop and pour. Offer hand-over-hand support if needed.
Add a simple goal: 'Fill to the line' or 'Can we move 3 scoops?'

observe: Child grasps scoop and coordinates pour with minimal spillage.
Child persists for 2‚Äì3 repetitions with interest.
variations: Easier: Use very large pasta pieces and extra-wide bowls.
Harder: Use a narrower container or small funnel with support.
cautions: Avoid very small grains if mouthing is strong‚Äîuse big pasta instead.
Supervise closely; clean spills to prevent slipping.

links.meetsExit: Child puts items into a container and transfers with support.

activities.title: Food Sounds & First Words Circle

materials.name: 3‚Äì4 picture cards of familiar foods (banana, apple, milk, rice)
Puppet or pointer for turn-taking

steps.text: Show one card at a time; label slowly ('ba-na-na'). Invite imitation of a sound or syllable.
Model two-word phrase with gesture: 'want banana', 'see apple' and encourage children to echo.
Use puppet to 'ask' each child what the food is; validate any vocalization/gesture as communication.

observe: Child attempts sound/word approximation for at least one item.
variations: Easier: Accept any vocal/gesture response and mirror it back.
cautions: Keep turns very short; avoid putting children on the spot.
Use neutral tone; accept nonverbal communication.

links.meetsExit: Child approximates or uses 1 food word/sound.

activities.title: Market Mini: Picture Shopping

materials.name: Small baskets, picture cards of foods, 3 'stall' mats (fruit, veg, grains)
2‚Äì3 large tokens (play money) for pretend exchange

steps.text: Set three 'stalls' with picture mats: fruit/veg/grains. Place mixed food cards in a central tray.
Give each child a basket and one token. Say: 'Let‚Äôs find fruit!' Model placing a fruit card in basket and 'pay' with a token.
Prompt the child to 'shop' for one item and place it on the matching stall mat.

observe: Child follows a simple one-step direction ('find fruit').
Child matches item to correct stall with cue.
variations: Easier: One stall at a time (fruit only).
Harder: Add 2-step direction ('find veg, then pay').
cautions: Keep tokens large to avoid mouthing.

links.meetsExit: Child completes one-step instruction with familiar vocabulary.
